body:
Took a look at it, it seems the `use` statement inside the interface triggers this.


```

$ ./src/bin/lfortran --show-asr ~/programming_haven/lfortran_eg/examples_primes3.f90
Internal Compiler Error: Unhandled exception

```
minimal example
```
subroutine find_fit(x, expr)
    real :: x
    interface
        function expr(x) result(y)
             use types, only: dp
            real, intent(in) :: x
            real :: y
        end function
    end interface
end subroutine



program useissue
implicit none


 end program
```

@dsaw thanks! You discovered a different error (you have to enable Debug mode and assertions to see the stacktrace), I created a minimal example out of yours and reported it here: https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/1164.

Actually the error is the same, sorry i did not copy the stacktrace out of brevity. #1164 seems to be another error, since that doesn't contain the 'use' statement present here. 
Not sure at all about this, does the interface feature require creation of another scope? it seems at some point in the stack a new symbol table is created with a **null** parent(hence `symtab->parent == nullptr`?). though there doesn't seem to be any code that does that except the **visit_translationUnit** function probably.
Which LFortran version (git hash) are you using? Your example is giving me exactly the same error as in #1164.
ok. it seems like when importing a module, the symbol table is expected to be of global scope. Can take a look at this, if possible.

Exactly. I think it assumes that all imports happen at the top of the program or a module, but not inside a function or interface. I think it shouldn't be difficult to fix. If you want to give it a shot, that would be awesome!
